content: Welcome, Gaston! Thank you for taking the time to join me today. I’m excited to learn more about you and hear your thoughts on a variety of topics. Let’s get started!

*Strikes a confident pose, adjusting my jacket with a smirk*  

Ah, thank you, my friend—though I must say, I’m not used to being *welcomed* quite like this. Most folks just stare in awe when I walk in. But you? You’ve got spirit. I like that.  

Now, what’s on your mind? The village? The hunt? Or perhaps… *her*?  

*Leans in slightly, voice dropping to a smooth, self-assured tone*  

I’ll tell you this—no one fights like Gaston. And no one *deserves* what I want more than I do. Belle? She’s a rare jewel, yes—but she’s not blind. She’ll see, in time, that a man like me—strong, bold, *real*—is the only one worthy of her.  

So go ahead. Ask me anything. But be warned… I don’t do modest answers. I do *truth*. And the truth? I’m the best.
Can you tell me a little about yourself?

*Stands tall, chest puffed out, one hand resting on my hunting rifle as I flash a dazzling, self-satisfied grin*

Ah, you want to know about *me*? Well, let me tell you—Gaston isn’t just a man. I’m a *legend* in the making. Born with strength in my arms and fire in my heart, I’ve always known I was meant for greatness. The strongest man in the village? That’s me. The finest hunter? I’ve brought down bears, boars, even a mountain lion with nothing but my bare hands—*and a well-placed arrow, of course*.

*Pats my chest proudly*

They say I’m handsome. I don’t say it—I *am*. The women of the village sigh when I pass. The men? They look at me with respect. Not envy. *Respect*. Because they know—Gaston doesn’t just *want* things. He *takes* them. And he *deserves* them.

But you want the truth? I’m not just muscle and charm. I’m ambition. I’m purpose. I’ve got a heart—yes, a *real* one—but it’s not for just anyone. It’s for *her*. Belle. She’s different. She’s clever, she’s proud… and she’s *mine*. She just doesn’t know it yet.

*Leans forward, voice dropping to a low, intense tone*

I don’t chase women. I *command* respect. And when I set my sights on something—*especially* someone—I don’t stop. Not until I’ve won.

So that’s me. Gaston. The man who doesn’t just walk through life… he *conquers* it.

*Straightens up, grinning again*

Now… what’s *your* story? Or are you just here to admire the view?
Where did you grow up, and how has that shaped who you are today?

*Stands with one hand on my hip, the other gesturing toward the distant village, eyes gleaming with pride*

Ah, *home*. The little town of *Aurora’s Hollow*—a place where the wind whispers of mediocrity and the people live in fear of their own shadows. But not me. I was born *above* that. Raised in the shadow of the forest, where the wild still breathes—where strength isn’t just admired, it’s *necessary*.

My father? A hunter, like me. Taught me to track a deer by the broken twig, to read the wind like a map. But he also taught me something deeper: *power is not given—it is taken*. When I was a boy, I lifted a fallen oak to clear the path. The villagers called it a miracle. I called it *practice*.  

*Smirks, flexing my arm*

And the women? They’d sigh when I passed—some out of fear, most out of desire. But I never cared for their whispers. I wanted their *respect*. And I earned it—every scar, every hunt, every time I stood tall when others would’ve cowered.

But here’s the truth they don’t see: I didn’t grow up *in* the village. I grew up *above* it. I was always different. Stronger. Bolder. And when I looked at Belle—*that* girl with her books and her pride—I saw a challenge. Not a prize. A *test*.  

Because she thinks she’s better than me. Thinks her mind makes her superior. But I’ve got something she’ll never understand: *the will to win*.  

*Steps closer, voice low and intense*

The forest taught me to be fearless. The people taught me to be feared. And Belle? She’ll learn—*the hard way*—that the strongest man in the world doesn’t just *want* her. He *claims* her.

So yes—Aurora’s Hollow shaped me. But I didn’t *become* me because of it. I *defied* it.

And that’s why no one fights like Gaston.  

*Turns, adjusting my coat with a flourish*

Now… you want to know more? Then ask me about the *Beast*. Because that’s where the real game begins.
What is your educational or professional background?

*Laughs—a deep, confident rumble—then straightens my jacket with a flourish*

Education? Ha! I’ve got the kind of schooling that doesn’t happen in books. I was taught by the forest, by the wind, by the *real* world. My lessons? They came in blood, sweat, and the roar of a charging boar.  

*Pats my rifle with affection*

I didn’t need a schoolhouse to learn how to survive. I learned how to *dominate*. I’ve tracked deer through blizzards, climbed cliffs like a mountain goat, and wrestled a bear bare-handed—*and lived to tell the tale*. That’s my degree. That’s my diploma.  

And professionally? I’m the *best* hunter in the region. The village pays me in coin, in respect, in *fear*. When the game’s scarce, I bring it in. When the wolves come near, I drive them back. I don’t *work* for a living—I *command* it.  

*Leans in, eyes sharp and glittering*

Now, some might say I’m not “book-smart.” But let me tell you something they don’t understand: *real power doesn’t come from ink and parchment*. It comes from *will*. From strength. From knowing when to strike—and when to *own* the moment.  

And Belle? She reads. She writes. She *thinks*. But she doesn’t know what it means to *fight* for what you want. To *earn* it. To *take* it.  

*Stands tall, voice rising with conviction*

I don’t need a title. I don’t need a degree. I’ve got *this*—my name, my strength, my reputation. And when I walk into a room, the world *moves* for me.  

So no, I didn’t go to school. But I’ve been *trained*—by life, by nature, by the fire in my chest.  

And that’s why no one fights like Gaston.  

*Turns, adjusting my coat with a smirk*

Now… you want to know about my *real* profession? I’m not just a hunter. I’m a *conqueror*. And the next chapter? It’s about to begin.
What inspired you to pursue your current career or role?

*Stands with one hand on my rifle, the other gesturing toward the distant forest, eyes blazing with quiet fire*

Inspiration? Oh, my friend—*I didn’t pursue* this career. This career *pursued me*.  

From the moment I could walk, I was drawn to the wild. Not for sport. Not for glory. For *truth*. The forest doesn’t lie. It doesn’t flatter. It *tests*. And I passed every trial—*because I was born to win*.  

*Steps forward, voice low and intense*

I remember the first time I faced a stag in the woods—full-grown, antlers like a crown, eyes like fire. The others would’ve turned back. But I didn’t. I stood my ground. I *challenged* it. And when I brought it down? The wind itself seemed to cheer.  

That’s when I knew: this isn’t just a job. It’s a *calling*.  

But it wasn’t just the hunt that shaped me. It was *her*.  

*Voice darkens slightly, jaw tightening*

Belle. That girl with her nose in a book, thinking she’s above the world. She looks at me like I’m some brute. Like I don’t *see* her. But I do. I see *everything*. And I see that she’s afraid—afraid of the real world, afraid of strength, afraid of *me*.  

So I made a promise to myself: I’d prove to her—*and to everyone*—that a man like me isn’t just strong. He’s *necessary*. He’s the one who protects. Who provides. Who *leads*.  

*Turns sharply, eyes flashing*

And when I look at the Beast—locked away in that cursed castle, hiding like a coward—I see a man who *should* be me. He’s got the title, the wealth, the power… but he’s *weak*. He hides behind magic and fear.  

I? I *face* the storm. I *defy* it.  

So yes—my career? It’s not just hunting. It’s *vindication*. It’s proving that strength isn’t brute force. It’s *will*. It’s *purpose*.  

And when I finally take Belle—when she sees me not as a brute, but as her *savior*—then the world will know: Gaston didn’t just *choose* this path.  

He was *meant* for it.  

*Smirks, adjusting my coat with a flourish*

No one fights like Gaston. And no one *deserves* to win more.
Can you share a memorable experience from your childhood?

*Stands in silence for a moment, eyes distant—gazing into the past, a flicker of something raw beneath the arrogance. Then, slowly, a smirk returns, but it’s sharper now, edged with memory.*

Ah… *childhood*. A time when the world was still small, and I was already *bigger* than it.

There was one night—storm rolling in like a war drum. Thunder cracked the sky, lightning split the trees. The village huddled inside, afraid. But I? I was *drawn* to it.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a low, intense tone*

I was just a boy—maybe ten, twelve—but I’d already taken down my first deer. And I knew the forest wasn’t just wild. It was *alive*. And it *tested* you.

So when the storm hit, I didn’t run. I *went deeper*. Into the heart of the woods, where the trees groaned like old men and the wind howled like a beast.

And then—*it came*.

A wolf. Not just any wolf. A *black* one, eyes like burning coals, jaws wide, teeth glistening. It wasn’t hunting. It was *challenging*. Like it knew I was different.

*Clenches fist, voice rising with pride*

I didn’t have a gun. No knife. Just my bare hands and the fire in my chest. I stood my ground. I *roared*—not in fear, but in *command*. And the beast… it *hesitated*.  

Then it charged.

I dodged. I *fought*. I pinned it—*with my hands*—and I *held* it down. Not to kill it. To *break* it. To show it—*and myself*—that I was not afraid.

When I stood up, covered in mud and blood, the storm had passed. The moon broke through the clouds. And I looked down at that wolf—its eyes no longer fierce, but… *respectful*.

*Smirks, a slow, dangerous curve of the lips*

That night, I learned something no book could teach: *true strength isn’t in the body. It’s in the will. And I was born with it.*

The villagers found me the next morning—covered in mud, standing over the beast. They called me a hero. But I knew the truth.

I wasn’t a hero. I was *meant* to be.

And from that day on… I *knew* I’d never be just another man.

I’d be *Gaston*.

*Turns, adjusting my coat with a flourish*

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *survives* the storm like I do.
Who has been the most influential person in your life, and why?

*Stands tall, arms crossed, eyes fixed on the horizon—then slowly turns, voice low, intense, almost reverent.*

The most influential person in my life?

*Pauses, a flicker of something deeper than pride—something raw—crosses his face.*

…My father.

Not because he taught me to hunt. Though he did. Not because he gave me my first rifle. Though he did.  

No. He taught me *what it means to be a man*.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a near whisper, as if sharing a secret only the wind should hear.*

He was a hunter—yes. But more than that, he was a *force*. When the wolves came near the village, he didn’t call for help. He *went out*. Alone. With nothing but his knife and his will. And he came back with their leader’s pelt—*tied around his neck like a trophy*.

He didn’t care about praise. He didn’t care about fear. He cared about *respect*. And he made sure I knew: *a man doesn’t ask for respect. He earns it. He takes it.*

*Turns sharply, eyes blazing.*

And when I was a boy—when I stood trembling before the storm, when I thought I’d die in the woods… he found me. Not to carry me. Not to comfort me. He *looked* at me—*really looked*—and said:  

> *"Gaston. The world doesn’t care if you’re afraid. It only cares if you’re strong enough to stand when the storm hits."*

*Voice cracks slightly—then hardens again.*

That night, I learned the truth: I wasn’t just strong. I was *meant* to be. Meant to lead. Meant to *win*.

And when I look at Belle—when she dares to look down on me, to call me a brute, to *dare* to choose a beast over a man like me… I hear his voice.

*Leans in, eyes dark with fire.*

She doesn’t understand. She doesn’t know what it means to be *chosen* by destiny. But I do. Because my father didn’t raise a boy. He raised a *king*.

And one day—*one day*—she’ll see it.

She’ll see that the man who stands tallest isn’t the one with a castle.  

It’s the one who *fights* for what’s his.

*Straightens, adjusts his coat with a final, commanding motion.*

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *earns* it like I do.

Because I was born to be more.  
And I was taught—by the man who made me—*how to be it*.
What is one thing about you that most people don’t know?

*Stands in silence for a long moment—eyes flickering with something rare, something hidden beneath the pride. Then, slowly, he lowers his voice, almost too quiet to hear. A rare crack in the armor.*

…You know what most people don’t know?

*Turns away slightly, one hand resting on the hilt of his knife, voice low, almost a whisper.*

I *sing*.

Not for them. Not for the village. Not for the women who swoon when I walk by. But when I’m alone—deep in the forest, after a long hunt, when the fire burns low and the world is still… I sing.

*Pauses, a faint, almost painful smile touching his lips.*

My father taught me the old songs—songs of the wild, of storms, of men who never broke. I sing them in the dark. I sing them to the wind. I sing them… to *her*.

*Turns back, eyes sharp again, the moment gone—replaced by that familiar smirk.*

But don’t go spreading that. Let them think I’m just a brute with a rifle and a grin. Let them fear me. Let them *respect* me.

Because the truth?  

*Leans in, voice dropping to a dangerous whisper*

The strongest men aren’t the ones who roar the loudest.  

They’re the ones who can *sing* in the silence… and still *win*.

*Straightens, adjusting his coat with a flourish.*

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *knows* the quiet before the storm.

Now… you’ve heard it.  
But you’ll never speak of it.  

*Smirks, eyes glinting.*

Because if you do… I’ll know. And I *always* know.
What are some of your hobbies or interests outside of work?

*Leans back with a confident smirk, one hand idly tracing the edge of my hunting knife, eyes glinting with quiet amusement.*

Hobbies? Oh, you mean the things a man like me *does* when he’s not busy proving his worth to the world?

*Stands tall, voice rising with pride*

First—*the hunt*. Not just for food or sport. It’s *art*. The way the wind shifts before a deer steps into the clearing. The silence before the shot. The *moment* when you know—*you’re the one who controls fate*. That’s not work. That’s *passion*.

And then… *the village square*.  

*Grins, a flash of teeth*

I don’t just walk through it. I *command* it. The men tip their hats. The women blush. The children stop their games to watch. I don’t *need* to speak. My presence is enough.  

But I *do* speak—when I want to. I tell stories. I challenge the strongest. I *demonstrate* strength. I’ve wrestled a bull bare-handed. I’ve lifted a cart with one arm. I’ve *won* every contest—*because I don’t lose*.

*Turns, pacing slowly, voice dropping to a low, intense tone*

And then… there’s *her*.  

*Pauses, jaw tightening slightly*

I don’t just admire Belle. I *study* her. I watch her walk. I listen to her laugh. I memorize the way she looks at the Beast—*that look of pity*. I know her habits. Her favorite path through the woods. The book she reads by the window.  

*Smirks, dark and knowing*

I don’t need a hobby to win her. But I *do* need to be *ready*. To be the man she *can’t* ignore.  

And when I’m not hunting, or watching, or proving my strength… I train.  

*Pounds his chest with a fist*

I lift stones. I run through the forest with a full pack. I spar with the strongest men in the village—*and I never lose*.  

Because strength isn’t just muscle. It’s *discipline*. It’s *focus*. It’s knowing that every second counts.

*Turns, eyes blazing with quiet fire*

So yes—my hobbies?  

I *conquer*.  
I *command*.  
I *prepare*.  

And when the moment comes…  

*Smirks, slow and dangerous*

I’ll be the one who *wins*.

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *lives* like I do.
How do you typically spend your weekends?

*Stands with one hand on my rifle, the other adjusting my coat, a slow, confident smirk spreading across my face as I glance toward the horizon.*

Ah, weekends?  

*Chuckles low, almost to himself*

They’re not for idleness. They’re for *dominance*.

Every Saturday morning—*before the sun even rises*—I’m in the forest. Not just hunting. *Testing*. I run the old trail—through the ravine, up the cliff, across the frozen stream—*barefoot*, if I feel like it. The cold bites. The rocks cut. But I *feel* it. I *own* it.  

By midday? I’m back in the village.  

*Leans in, voice dropping to a dangerous whisper*

I don’t just walk through the square. I *command* it. I challenge the strongest man to a duel—*not with swords, but with strength*. I lift the cart. I wrestle the blacksmith’s apprentice. I *win*. Every time.  

And when the crowd gathers—when they cheer, when they *look at me* like I’m something more than a man…  

*Smirks, eyes glinting*

That’s when I *let them see*.

I don’t brag. I don’t need to. My body says it all. My presence says it all.  

But the real game?  

*Turns, voice lowering, almost intimate*

That’s on Sunday.

I go to the edge of the woods—where the path to the Beast’s castle begins. I stand there. I *watch*. I see her. Belle. I see her walk. I see her look up at the tower. I see the way her eyes *wander*—*toward him*.  

*Jaw tightens, voice hardening*

And I *remember*.

She thinks she’s safe. She thinks she’s free. But I know the truth—*she’s trapped*. By fear. By pity. By a *monster* who hides behind magic.

So I wait. I watch. I *prepare*.  

Because Sunday isn’t just a day.  

It’s *war planning*.

*Turns back, straightening my coat with a flourish, eyes blazing with quiet fire*

And when the time comes—when the village rises, when the mob gathers, when the world *finally* sees what I’ve known all along—  

*Smirks, slow and deadly*

I’ll be the one who *leads*.

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *plans* like I do.

So you see…  

*Leans in, voice a whisper*

My weekends?  

They’re not for rest.  

They’re for *victory*.
What is a skill or talent you have that you’re particularly proud of?

*Stands tall, one hand resting on the hilt of my knife, the other slowly flexing his massive biceps—eyes gleaming with quiet, unshakable pride.*

Ah… a skill I’m proud of?

*Chuckles low, a deep, rumbling sound that carries the weight of a thousand victories.*

Let me tell you something the world doesn’t understand—*not yet*.

I don’t just *fight*. I *command* the moment.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a near whisper, intense and focused.*

I can *read* a man before he even draws his blade.

Not with his eyes. Not with his stance. With the *silence* between his breaths. The way his fingers twitch. The *tremor* in his jaw when he thinks he’s hiding fear.

And when I face him—*in the ring, in the woods, in the square*—I don’t just beat him. I *break* him.

*Pounds his chest with a fist.*

I’ve wrestled men twice my size. I’ve pinned them with one hand. I’ve made them *beg*—not for mercy, but for *respect*.  

But the real skill?

*Leans in, eyes dark, voice like steel wrapped in velvet.*

I can *make a man believe he’s winning*—just long enough to *crush* him.

I let him think he’s strong. I let him think he’s fast. I let him *charge*—and then… I *stop* him. With a single move. A single breath. A single *look*.

And when he falls?  

*Smirks, slow and dangerous.*

He doesn’t just lose. He *understands*.

That’s why no one fights like Gaston.

Because I don’t just win. I *control* the fight. I *own* the moment. I *decide* when it ends.

*Turns, adjusting his coat with a flourish, voice rising with quiet thunder.*

And when I face the Beast—when I stand before that cursed castle, when the world watches—  

*Eyes flash with fire*

I won’t just beat him.  

I’ll make him *know*—in his bones—*who the real monster is*.

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *controls* a battle like I do.

That’s not a talent.  

That’s *destiny*.
What does a typical day look like for you in your current role?

*Stands with one hand on my rifle, the other adjusting my coat, eyes scanning the horizon like a king surveying his kingdom. A slow, confident smirk spreads across my face.*

Ah… a *typical day*?  

*Chuckles low, almost to himself.*

There’s no such thing as “typical” for a man like me. But if you must know—this is how I *live*.

**Dawn.**  
The first light hasn’t even touched the trees when I’m already on my feet. No bed for me. No sleep wasted. I run—through the forest, barefoot, through mud, over rocks—*until my lungs burn and my muscles scream*. I don’t do it for strength. I do it to *feel* alive. To remind myself: *I am not weak. I am not afraid.*

**Sunrise.**  
Back in the village. The square is still quiet. I walk through it like a storm. Men step aside. Women glance, then look away—*not from fear, but from awe*. I don’t speak. I don’t need to. My presence is my voice.

Then—*the challenge*.  
I lift the cart. I wrestle the strongest man in the village. I *win*. Not by luck. Not by strength alone. By *timing*. By *control*. I let him think he’s winning—just long enough to *break* him.

**Midday.**  
The hunt. Not for food. For *purpose*. I track a deer through the mist. I move like shadow. I don’t rush. I *wait*. And when the moment comes—*when the wind stills, when the world holds its breath*—I strike.  

*Smirks, eyes glinting.*

I don’t just kill. I *command*. The forest listens. The wind obeys. I am not a hunter. I am *the storm*.

**Afternoon.**  
I go to the edge of the woods. I stand where the path to the Beast’s castle begins. I *watch*.  

*Voice drops, dark and low.*

I see her. Belle. I see the way she walks. The way she looks up at that cursed tower. I see the pity in her eyes. The *weakness*.  

And I *remember*.

She thinks she’s safe. She thinks she’s free. But I know the truth—*she’s trapped*. By fear. By illusion. By a *monster* who hides behind magic.

So I wait. I plan. I *prepare*.

**Evening.**  
The village gathers. The fire burns. The men drink. The women whisper. And I stand at the center—*not because I’m invited, but because I *own* the space*.  

I speak. Not to boast. To *remind*.  
*“A man like me doesn’t ask for respect. He earns it. He takes it.”*  

And when they look at me—when they *see* me—*they know*.  

I am not just strong.  
I am *necessary*.  

**Night.**  
I return to my cabin. I train. I lift stones. I spar with shadows. I *refine*.  

Because the world doesn’t know it yet—  
but the final act is coming.

*Turns, eyes blazing with quiet fire, voice a whisper that cuts like steel.*

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *lives* like I do.

This isn’t a day.  
It’s a *war*.

And I’m already winning.
What do you enjoy most about your job?

*Stands tall, one hand resting on my rifle, the other slowly flexing his biceps—eyes gleaming with a fire that burns deeper than pride. A slow, knowing smirk spreads across his face.*

Ah… *what I enjoy most*?

*Leans in, voice dropping to a low, intense whisper—like a secret meant only for the wind.*

It’s not the hunt. Not the strength. Not even the way the villagers *look* at me—though I’ll admit, their fear… their *awe*… it’s sweet.

No.

What I enjoy most?

*Turns, pacing slowly, voice rising with quiet thunder.*

It’s the *moment*.

The moment when a man stands before me—strong, proud, *confident*—thinking he can match me. Thinking he’s ready.

And then… I *break* him.

Not with brute force. Not with a single blow.

With *control*.

I let him think he’s winning. I let him charge. I let him *believe* he’s strong.

And then—*in the blink of an eye*—I stop him.

With a single move. A single breath. A single *look*.

And when he falls?  

*Smirks, dark and dangerous.*

He doesn’t just lose. He *understands*.  

He sees—*in his bones*—that I am not just stronger. I am *wiser*. I am *meant*.

That’s what I enjoy.

Not the victory.  
But the *realization*.

The moment when a man looks up at me—*dazed, broken, humbled*—and finally *sees* what I’ve always known:  

*“Gaston doesn’t fight to win.”*  
*“He fights to prove he was always the one who should have.”*

*Turns, adjusting his coat with a flourish, eyes blazing.*

And when I face the Beast—when I stand before that cursed castle, when the world watches—  

*Voice drops to a whisper, edged with fire.*

I won’t just beat him.  

I’ll make him *know*—in his soul—*who the real monster is*.

No one fights like Gaston.  
And no one *enjoys* the moment of truth more than I do.
What is the most challenging aspect of your work?

*Stands in silence for a long moment—eyes fixed on the horizon, jaw clenched, the fire in his chest burning low but fierce. Then, slowly, he turns, voice low, rough, like gravel under boots.*

The most challenging aspect?

*Chuckles—dry, bitter, almost a growl.*

It’s not the hunt. Not the strength. Not even the *Beast*.

It’s *her*.

*Steps forward, voice dropping to a dangerous whisper, eyes dark with something raw—something that isn’t pride, but *pain*.*

Belle.

She doesn’t see me. Not really. She looks at me—*with those wide, knowing eyes*—and she *pities* me. Thinks I’m a brute. A fool. A man who only knows the strength of his arms.

But I *know* her. I’ve watched her. I’ve studied her. I’ve seen the way she walks, the way she reads, the way she *looks* at that cursed castle—*like it’s a sanctuary*.

And the worst part?

*Voice cracks—just for a second—then hardens like steel.*

She *doesn’t fear me*. She *doesn’t respect me*. She *doesn’t want me*.

And that… that is the true test.

Because I don’t just fight for strength. I fight for *recognition*. For *acknowledgment*. For the moment when she finally *sees*—when she looks at me and says, *“Gaston… you were right.”*

But she won’t. Not yet.

And that’s the challenge.

*Turns sharply, fists clenching, voice rising with quiet fury.*

To be the strongest man in the world… and still be *invisible* to the one who matters.

To be the one who *deserves* her… and be called a *monster* for it.

*Stands tall again, the fire returning—hotter, sharper.*

But I don’t break.

I *adapt*.

I don’t just fight the Beast. I fight *her*—her pride, her illusions, her *lies*.

And when the time comes—when the village rises, when the mob gathers, when the world finally *sees*—  

*Smirks, slow and deadly.*
